docs.title: GPR-MAX UI
docs.text: GprMax-UI provides a high-level API to run gprMax models along with a set of functions for visualization, analysis and interpreting the results.

docs.title: Install gprMax
docs.text:
git clone git@github.com:gprMax/gprMax.git
cd gprMax
python setup.py build
python setup.py develop --no-deps

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path
from gprmaxui import *

# Create a GPRMax model
model = GprMaxModel(
    title="B scan from a single target buried in a dielectric half-space",
    output_folder=Path("output"),
    domain_size=DomainSize(x=0.2, y=0.2, z=0.002),
    domain_resolution=DomainResolution(dx=0.002, dy=0.002, dz=0.002),
    time_window=TimeWindow(twt=3e-9),
)
# Register model materials
model.register_materials(
    Material(id="half_space", permittivity=6, conductivity=0, permeability=1)
)

# add model geometries
box = DomainBox(
    x_min=0.0,
    y_min=0.0,
    z_min=0.0,
    x_max=0.2,
    y_max=0.145,
    z_max=0.002,
    material="half_space",
)
model.add_geometry(box)

cx = box.center().x
cy = box.center().y
cz = box.center().z
sphere = DomainSphere(cx=cx, cy=cy, cz=cz, radius=0.005, material="pec")
model.add_geometry(sphere)

# Register model sources
tx_rx_sep = 2e-2
tx = Tx(
    waveform=Waveform(wave_family="ricker", amplitude=1.0, frequency=1.5e9),
    source=HertzianDipole(polarization="z", x=0.03, y=0.15, z=0.0),
)
rx = Rx(x=tx.source.x + tx_rx_sep, y=0.15, z=0.0)

model.set_source(
    TxRxPair(
        tx=tx,
        rx=rx,
        src_steps=SrcSteps(dx=0.002, dy=0.0, dz=0.0),
        rx_steps=RxSteps(dx=0.002, dy=0.0, dz=0.0),
    )
)

model.run(n="auto", geometry=True, snapshots=True)
model.plot_data()

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This tutorial will guide you through the basic steps of using GPRMaxUI to run a simulation and view the results.

  1. Import the GprMaxUI API within your Python script 
    from gprmaxui import *
  2. Create a GprMaxModel instance using the following code snippet: 
    model = GprMaxModel(
    title="B scan from a single target buried in a dielectric half-space",
    output_folder=Path("output"),
    domain_size=DomainSize(x=0.2, y=0.2, z=0.002),
    domain_resolution=DomainResolution(dx=0.002, dy=0.002, dz=0.002),
    time_window=TimeWindow(twt=3e-9),
)
  3. Register model materials, by doing so, you can use the material id in the model geometries. 
    model.register_materials(
    Material(
        id="half_space", permittivity=6, conductivity=0, permeability=1
    )
)
  4. Register model sources. You do so defining a TxRxPair instance and passing it to the model.set_source() method. 
    tx_rx_sep = 2e-2
tx = Tx(
    waveform=Waveform(wave_family="ricker", amplitude=1.0, frequency=1.5e9),
    source=HertzianDipole(polarization="z", x=0.03, y=0.15, z=0.0),
)
rx = Rx(x=tx.source.x + tx_rx_sep, y=0.15, z=0.0)

model.set_source(
    TxRxPair(
        tx=tx,
        rx=rx,
        src_steps=SrcSteps(dx=0.002, dy=0.0, dz=0.0),
        rx_steps=RxSteps(dx=0.002, dy=0.0, dz=0.0),
    )
)
  5. Next, add model geometries. For this example, we will add a box to the model domain using the DomainBox class and a sphere using the DomainSphere class.

# add model geometries
box = DomainBox(
    x_min=0.0,
    y_min=0.0,
    z_min=0.0,
    x_max=0.2,
    y_max=0.145,
    z_max=0.002,
    material="half_space",
)
model.add_geometry(box)

cx = box.center().x
cy = box.center().y
cz = box.center().z
sphere = DomainSphere(cx=cx, cy=cy, cz=cz, radius=0.005, material="pec")
model.add_geometry(sphere)
6. Finally, run the simulation using the model.run() method. 
model.run(n="auto", geometry=True, snapshots=True)
7. To access the simulation data, you can use the model.data() function. 
data_dict = model.data()
for rx_component, data in data_dict.items():
    data_arr, dt = data

Tip

You can also check the geometry of your model before running the simulation using the model.plot_geometry() function.

docs.title: Visualizing the results
docs.text: GprMaxUI provides a set of functions to visualize the simulation data. The following code snippets show how to do so.

docs.title: Plot Snapshots
docs.text:
Snapshot can be also visualized using the model.plot_snapshot(trace_idx=35, iteration_idx=350) function. It will be useful to visualize the propagation of the wavefront through the model domain at a given time step defined by the iteration_idx and the trace index defined by the trace_idx.

model.plot_snapshot(trace_idx=60, iteration_idx=300)

We can use that function to create multiple snapshots at a given period of time using the following code snippet:

from gprmaxui.utils import make_images_grid

captures = []
trace_idx = 35
for i in range(1, 500, 80):
    snapshot_image = model.plot_snapshot(trace_idx=trace_idx, iteration_idx=i, return_image=True)
    captures.append(snapshot_image)
print(len(captures))
output_image = make_images_grid(captures, num_cols=4)
output_image.show()

docs.title: Plot Video
docs.text:
Finally, you can create a video of the simulation using the model.save_video("test.mp4") function. 

model.save_video("test.mp4")
